title: Athens is the only eurozone city with sub-par living conditions
text:
Print 
The Greek debt crisis has knocked six percentage points off Athens' liveability rating over the last five years, meaning it is the only city in Western Europe without top-tier living conditions 
Greece's economic difficulties have made Athens the only Western European city to drop out of the top tier of the annual liveability index published by the Economic Intelligence Unit. 
The austerity-stricken Greek capital , which has been under capital controls since late June as the country tussled with creditors over its debt repayments, has seen its liveability rating drop from 77.5pc to 75.3pc over the last year. 
Athens, which fell from 69th to 72nd in the 140 places ranked, is the only city in the eurozone with a liveability rating that falls short of the 80pc threshold for cities that have few, if any, tangible setbacks to lifestyle. 
The Economist Intelligence Unit suggests that a person being moved for work purposes to a city with a score under 80pc should be given an extra financial allowance from their employer. 
Athens' score has dropped by six percentage points over the last five years, making it one of the largest fallers during the period. 
Other places that have suffered steep declines in liveability over the last five years include the Middle Eastern cities of Damascus, Tripoli, Tunis, Cairo and Bahrain, as well as Detroit, which declared bankruptcy in 2013 with $18.5bn (£11.8bn) of debt. 
Kiev is the second-largest faller on the index, losing 26 percentage points since 2010 amid ongoing political tensions between Ukraine and Russia , while Moscow and St Petersburg have also seen their scores decline by 6pc and 4pc respectively. 
"Civil unrest, acts of terror and violence have triggered stability declines around the world," the report said. "High-profile terrorist shootings in France and Tunisia, and the ongoing actions of Islamic State in the Middle East, have created a further heightened threat of terrorism in many countries." 
Paris dropped from 16th place last year to number 29 on the ranking following the shootings at the Charlie Hebdo office and several terror attacks. 
The Economist Intelligence Unit’s liveability survey assesses the living conditions of 140 cities across the five categories of stability, healthcare, culture and environment, education and infrastructure. 
Melbourne was found to be the most liveable location in the world for the fifth year running, with a score of 97.5 out of 100, followed by Vienna, with 97.4. 
London rose two places from 55th to 53rd, with a liveability rating of 87.2. However, Manchester ranked higher than the British capital with 88.8, climbing from 51 to 46 in the ranking.
